Gaseous chlorine and/or sulfur dioxide is drawn by a vacuum though one of the two rotometers,
which serve to feed chlorine at a specified rate to the ejector system. The gaseous chlorine and
sulfur dioxide is mixed with treated water. The chlorine solution is injected into the treated
wastewater at the beginning of the chlorine contact chamber and the sulfur dioxide is injected at
the end of the chlorine contact chamber. The wastewater effluent is then discharged into Mobile
River.

68.155(c) Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Steps

Worst-case and alternative case release scenarios were conducted as required for the Prevention
Program 2 process. Emergency response activities have been coordinated with local responders
which are also required for the Prevention Program 2 process. Lastly, a program and document
management system is in place. The Prevention Program 2 process allows streamlined prevention
program requirements; however, implementation of the following elements are required:
¿ safety information,
¿ hazard review,
¿ operating procedures,
¿ training,
¿ maintenance,
¿ compliance audits, and
¿ incident investigations.

In 2010, GMC, with the assistance of C. C. Williams facility management and staff, conducted a
compliance audit and a hazard review of the chlorine system using the What-If analysis. The
results of the audit and hazard review identified recommended changes in operating, maintenance,
and other process safety management procedures that would improve the overall safety of the
chlorine system. The results of the audit and the hazard review, in addition to recommendations
made, are documented and are maintained as part of the RMP records. In 2016 and 2021, this What
If analysis was reviewed to ensure the findings were still valid.

68.155(d) Five-Year Accident History

The C. C. Williams facility has had no accidental releases of chlorine within the last

five (5) years
that have resulted in on-site injuries, off-site injuries, and/or off-site impacts.
68.155(e) Emergency Response Program
If a release were to occur, a C. C. Williams facility employee would immediately contact the Mobile
County Emergency Management Agency (MCEMA), whose members are aware of the presence of
chlorine and sulfur dioxide at the facility. The MCEMA would dispatch experience HAZMAT
personnel trained to respond to such emergencies. The emergency response procedures are
outlined in the MAWSS Standard Operating Procedure - Emergency Response Coordination with
Local Responders, which was last updated by Jacobs Engineering in 2019.
The area that stores the one-ton cylinders is fully enclosed and is equipped with a caustic scrubber
for mitigation of a release. The caustic scrubber system is equipped with chlorine and sulfur
dioxide detectors that will automatically activate the scrubber system if a chlorine concentration
of three (3) parts per million or great is present. In addition, MAWSS has installed emergency
chlorine and sulfur dioxide valve actuators, which will shut off gas flow to the feed system from the
one-ton cylinders within 30 seconds after detecting a leak. The system also contains an emergency
panic button located outside of the storage area to allow for operator-initiated emergency shutoff.

68.155(f) Safety Improvements

Recommendations for safety improvements that have been identified in current and previous
compliance audits and Hazard Reviews are documented in the RMP.

68.155(b) Stationary Source and Substance Handled
The C. C. Williams facility stores and handles chlorine and sulfur dioxide, and is a stationary source
potentially subject to 40 CFR 68. The facility has four (4) one-ton chlorine cylinders and two (2) oneton
sulfur dioxide cylinders connected to the proportional feed system at all times. A header pipe
supplies chlorine to the inlet side of the chlorine contact chamber. A chlorine solution is also
delivered to the splitter box of the primary settling basins, a spray system to control foam near the
influent and effluent of the primary biological reactors and at the intermediate pumping station. The
delivery of a chlorine solution to various locations within the treatment process is to provide a more
stable treatment process and guard against upsets. Similarly, a header pipe supplies sulfur dioxide
only to the outlet (discharge) side of the Chlorine Contact Chamber. In addition to the two (2) sulfur

40 CFR 68.155 Introduction

The USEPA's RMP regulation, 40 CFR 68, was published in the Federal Register on June 20, 1996, and
developed to assist facilities in preventing accidental release of highly toxic or flammable
chemicals. The RMP regulation applies to an owner or operator of a stationary source that has more
than a threshold quantity of a regulated substance in a process per 40 CFR 68.115.
The USEPA has established three (3) tiers of requirements to reduce the level of effort for facilities
with a lower risk of offsite impacts. These tiers are known as Programs 1, 2 and 3. Program 1 is
defined by a process that has had no accidental release causing offsite impacts in the past five (5)
years or the nearest public receptor is beyond the distance to a toxic or flammable endpoint based
on the worst-case release scenario. Program 3 applies to a process that is subject to Occupational
Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) or is not classified in
any of the Program 3 NAICS codes defined in 40 CFR 68.10(d)(1). Program 2 applies to processes not
defined by Program 1 or 3. Therefore, the C. C. Williams Wastewater Treatment Facility processes
are subject to Program 2 requirements.

The Mobile Area Water and Sewer System (MAWSS) operates the C. C. Williams facility located at
1600 Yeend Street in Mobile, Alabama. Chlorine is used as a disinfectant for treated wastewater,
with the facility storing approximately twelve (12) one-ton cylinders containing chlorine under
normal operating conditions. In addition to chlorine cylinders, there are six (6) one-ton cylinders of
sulfur dioxide, used to remove free chlorine residuals from the treated wastewater, stored on-site.
As stated above, chlorine is used as a disinfectant in the treatment of wastewater and sulfur dioxide
is used for the dechlorination of the wastewater effluent after chlorination and before discharge.
The C. C. Williams facility utilizes more than the

threshold quantity of chlorine and sulfur dioxide as
defined in 40 CFR 68.150; therefore, the facility is required to submit an RMP including both
regulated chemicals. The initial RMP was submitted by June 21, 1999. A five (5) year update was
made by Malcolm Pirnie in January 2005 updating the offsite consequence analyses determining
whether the parameters and assumptions used are still valid. To comply with the five (5) year update
requirement in 2010, Goodwyn Mills Cawood (GMC) reviewed the offsite consequence analyses to
determine whether the parameters assumptions used are still valid and to make any necessary
changes to update the RMP. In 2016 and 2021, GMC and the Operations staff the CC Williams Facility
reviewed and updated the plan.

68.155(a) Accidental Release and Emergency Response Policies

The C. C. Williams facility has established procedures to ensure the integrity of the chlorination and
dechlorination systems, and minimize the potential for releases. Standard protocols have been
established for items such as systems operations, maintenance, training, and incident investigation.
To ensure the safety of the C. C. Williams facility chlorination, the facility relies on the commitment
and team effort of its employees and suppliers.
The C. C. Williams facility has a minimum of two (2) and a maximum of thirty (30) employees on duty
at any given time, which are trained on safe operation of the chlorination and dechlorination
systems. Daily inspections of the areas storing and/or using chlorine and sulfur dioxide are
conducted by the facility employees. The area that stores the containers is fully enclosed and is
equipped with a caustic scrubber for control of a chlorine or sulfur dioxide release. The caustic
scrubber system is equipped with detectors that will automatically activate the scrubber system if
a chlorine or sulfur dioxide concentration of three (3) parts per million or greater is present. In
